By DAVID HOELSCHER
President Lincoln Gordon said
Tuesday that any student who
contributes to a "substantial
disruption" of the University will
not be allowed to receive or
continue to receive federal aid.
His statement followed the
passage by the Joint
House-Senate Conference of a
new anti-riot provision of the
higher education bill. The Bill,
which authorizes administration
officials to take such action,gives
the University the responsibility
of deciding what will be
considered " substantial
disruption" of the school.
Substantial Disruption
Gordon explained that he
interprets "substantial
disruption" to mean any activity
which impinges upon the rights
and actions of either students or
faculty members. He cited such
activities as occupation of a
building, "mill-ins" and massive,
prolonged student strikes as
examples.
The provision does require
that once the University removes
a student from federal aid, he will
be ineligible for further federal
assistance for three years.
Gordon added that the
Administration does not have
specific guidelines for
determining whether student
protest is seriously disruptive.
"Such guidelines are not
necessary at Hopkins," he said,
"because for one thing the
faculty and administration are
not a split over student
participation as they were in
Columbia University and
secondly, because we've
discovered that students do not
want to play an active role in the
administration of the
University."
Disruption Unlikely
The President feels that it is
highly unlikely that Hopkins will
undergo disruptive student
demonstrations to the degree and
intensity of those that were seen
at Columbia.
For this reason, he hopes that
all disciplinary action will be
handled by the individual Deans,
the Director of Student Affairs
and, perhaps, the Committee of
Student Affairs. The President
would then handle any appeals of
individual cases.

Eisenhower Defends Violence Commission's Operation
By BRUCE DRAKE
In an interview with the
Dr. Milton
News-Letter,
Eisenhower, Chairman of the
President's Commission on the
Causes and Prevention of
Violence, reiterated his
intentions to analyze the recent
wave of campus violence as well
as last month's Chicago's
disorders.
Dr. Eisenhower, in his
remarks, firmly defended his
Commission in the face of the
continuing criticism which the
Commission has received since its
inception following the
assasination of Senator Robert
Kennedy,last June.
Critics have derided the
make-up of the Violence
Commission focusing particularly

on Eric Hoffer, author of The
True Believer, whom one
columnist called a "pop
philosopher," and Senator
Roman Hruska, a staunch
opponent of gun control
legislation.
Reasons For Commission
Others have charged that the
establishment of the Violence
Commission has reinforced the
belief that "this is the kind of
thing Presidents do when they
don't know what else to do."
Specifically, Dr. Eisenhower has
been faced with the accusation
that his Commission was set up to
reassure the American people
that "something was being done"
about the assasinations of Robert
Kennedy and Martin Luther
King.

Dr. Eisenhower, however,
flatly denied that he would allow
the Commission to be used as
"sort of a soothing balm to the
public." He added that he "would
have no inducement to make a
show for a Democratic
president."
Generally, Dr. Eisenhower
seemed unconcerned about the
criticism, shrugging it off by
saying that he "didn't mind
people saying it's useless."
Ironically, in the face of the
criticism and lack of attention
which the Commission has
received, he gives the impression
that he would like the
Commission to become a
permanent fixture.
He is already looking ahead to

see if the next President will
continue the Commission, even
though formal hearings started
only a week ago. Eisenhower also
expressed the hope that the
National Science Foundation and
National Institute of Health
would continue the
Commission's work.
The Violence Commission, as
presently constituted, does not
have the backing and resources of
past Presidential groups like the
Warren or Kerner Commissions.
Dr. Eisenhower conceded that
the Commission will "just have to
wait and see if we'll get the
resources to do the job that we
think needs to be done."

Late last April, after more than
eight months of petitioning and
protest, one-thousand Columbia
University students, led by Students for a Democratic Society,
occupied five campus buildings.
They were demanding an end
both to the University's ties with
the Institute for Defense Analysis
(a corporation connected with
twelve universities which does warfare research for the government),
and to the construction of a
University gymnasium in Harlem
— an example of Columbia's "racist" expansion into the black
community.
After the police cleared
the buildings and the campus,
injuring 150 persons, including
professors, and arresting more
than seven-hundred, Columbia
was shut down by a strike involving a majority of the students.
Amnestyfor all strikers became

"Free Huey" demonstrations, in

The world will face
catastrophic famine within 17
years unless immediate steps are
taken to curb population growth,
said Dr. William D. McElroy in
remarks prepared for delivery
before the American Institute of
Biological Sciences in Columbus,
Ohio.
McElroy, Chairman of JHU'S
Biology Department and Director
of the McCollum-Pratt Institute,
said that next to the search for
peace the population explosion is
the world's greatest problem.
Positive Action
He suggested a number of
steps that should be taken
immediately to help solve the
population problem, including
such steps as developing the
technology of farming the
oceans, radically altering the U.S.
farm policy, and setting up
world-wide institutions for
population control.
"Some feel that the battle to
feed the world population is now
lost, and that it is a foregone
conclusion that by 1985 we will
have world • wide famines in
which hundreds of millions of
people will starve to death,"
McElroy said. "I must admit that
I see no major crash program
presently existing which would
lead me to disagree with this
conclusion."
While the U.S. would not
experience the famine, it would
feel the resultant chaos in
two-thirds of the world caused
by the starvation. Everything
from balance of trade to political
orientation will be influenced by
the lack of available food.
By 1983 the world population
will reach 4.5 billion compared to
present population estimates of

about 3.4 billion. Considering
normal progress in agriculture, at
this point in time the world will
simply be unable to support that
many living creatures.
"In nature," McElroy said,
"no animal, plant, or bacterial
population has ever maintained a
logrithmic phase of growth for
very long. The major factors that
slow this rate of growth are
exhaustion of food supply,
accumulation of toxic products,
decimation through disease, or
the effects of some outside lethal
agent which kills a high
proportion of the population...I
leave it to your imagination
which of these factors might
apply to the human population."
Birth Control
The recent encyclical of Pope
Paul VI compounds the problem,
said Dr. McElroy "It is entirely
contrary to all we know in
biology." In the less educated
countries the effect will be
tremendous and dangerous. The
effect of prolonging life through
better medicine and advanced
surgery and infancy techniques
adds to the problem.
Furthermore, if the problem
of population growth is the
number two problem of the
world, then it certainly must be
placed along side the number one
problem—namely the search for
lasting peace.
"It needs the same status and
the same amount of money. Most
of all, it needs the leadership of
the United States in convincing
the world that something must be
done, and done now, to decrease
the growth of the world population and to increase food production dramatically and immediately.

seventeen sophomores made the

?play the platoon system.

October 5 when the Jays meet the
Dips of Franklin & Marshall in the
home opener.
